posts.com: Hawaii is fucking gorgeous. The locals are friendly enough. The weather is perfect. The price for hotels, condos and restaurants is absolutely insane. One afternoon we got a small salad and a side of fried calamari with 2 drinks at the resort in Maui. We get out bill, it;s $90 not including the tip. The Calamari was $45. My beer was $17. I was fucking shocked. We ended up staying in a condo and I would go to the grocery and pick up fish to grill instead. We saved 100's of dollars that way. I really loved Maui, but I wouldn't go back unless we had a free place to stay or we were going to a conference. My gf and I spent more money in Maui in a week than we did for 4 weeks in Europe. My next beach trip is going to be Croatia.

Overall great experience, can definitely recommend.

Vietnam, Philippines, Thailand already has you covered and for a fraction of the price (and better infrastructure these days, no homeless, no druggies, no crime). Want an island where everyone is laid back, wears cool shirts and has a unique culture? Bali and Indonesia has you covered and for a fraction of the price. Want an overpriced tropical environment that based in the United States? Florida has got you covered, and with a much better local state government, low to no state taxes, (slightly) less inflated prices and no dumb COVID hysteria which is still very stubbornly persistent here in Hawaii. Hawaii is way overvalued for what you get these days and your money is better spent elsewhere, even the locals now are fleeing to Vegas.

Western colonies could maintain these countries through superior force of arms but the natives can't muster a strong enough monopoly on violence for the state to maintain stability (because people's loyalties are with their ethnicity rather then their nationality).

- National governments peacefully giving up territory, power and natural resources for more natural national borders.
- The rest of the world ngaf and letting some country have their genocide uninterrupted and whole ethnicities being destroyed to create monocultures.

What remains is to hope that increased wealth, security and standard of living will offset the intranational conflicts lessen turmoil until you get a somewhat working multicultural state.
An optimistic view is that this is on it's way in the most successful sub-saharan states but even those still are far from the safest places in the world.

With low calorie intake you can eat cheaply.
Foods expiring are on discount
Fresh bread sold late in the afternoon example at tesco on Uk is often half price.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390893
I've done two families together and the understanding that we could split up meant a big argument just resulted in splitting for a day and joining back up after having cooled off. My scattershot advice:

Try to get people to say what they want to do as early as possible. Some people may want to watch Fantasmic, some may want a themed dinner, etc. Finding out late in the day can lead to arguments.
Sort out a basic itinerary early. Allow for flexy days if someone wants to go to Gatorworld, do an airboat ride, there are multiple days with activities not set in stone where you can split up for the whole day.
Do not go to Magic Kingdom on the weekend. Chances are you're flying in on the weekend, they will want their first day to be at the Magic Kingdom. Do not do it, tell them how that park is hell on weekends.
Try to stick together for the "main" days, the more people riding on things together, the better.
Sort out your toilet breaks and minimise them. You waste so much fucking time in big groups because of constant long toilet breaks.
Don't over pressure people to go on rides they can't take, not only may they have a miserable time, they may believe they're going to keep getting pressured for other rides they don't want to go on.
Continuing on that let people go on other rides whilst they wait, you can meet after.
Try to avoid quiet people getting dominated: "Lol no we don't want to go on the Little Mermaid ride!" "oh... ok". Especially likely to happen to people who can't take big coasters. Try to stop dominant voices getting into the habit of speaking for the group
Avoid any people becoming the "+2". Easy for the same people to always be the last ones in the line who go in a different car from everyone else on rides.
Sort out phones, everyone must be contactable. Parks have free wifi everywhere if people don't have roaming.
Don't make people reliant on "the group" for transport

Get everyone to get the My Disney Experience app and link it all together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2384843
>Would you recommend visiting Adelaide?
Adelaide has fantastic food, an actual nightlife district (Hindley/Rundle St, but their sidestreets are where the real fun is, with heaps of fantastic cocktail bars, especially Peel St & Leigh St), and is very easy to commute around, along with being far cheaper than Melbourne and Sydney.
As far as beaches go, Adelaide has a lot of nice ones, though if you prefer warmer water and more of a beachside culture, then you'd want Queensland.
If you're coming to Adelaide, there's also a fair few worldclass wineries less than a half hour out of the CBD, and a great deal of great distilleries and breweries. If you're not a drinker, there's fantastic walking trails through the parklands and the Adelaide Hills. It's pretty easy to get to nature from Adelaide too.

>>2390197
That is a tough one. Maybe the Hard Rock cafe on Gion? As far as I know it is the only HRC that is not 200% cookie cutter. It's supposedly the only one that serves local foods instead of just serving whatever Americana you get at every other HRC around the globe.
If you don't want to do the temple/shrine meme why bother going to Kyoto at all?
Actually though, you could climb up the mountain to the Shogunzuka Seiryuden Temple. The hike starts from the graveyard at Chion-in temple and there are a couple of really nice viewpoint along the way. At the top the Shogunzaka isn't really a temple temple, it used to be Kyoto Police dojo in the 1940's and now it hosts a few mikos selling the usual temple stuff, and there's a nice garden and a few viewing decks giving a nice view of Kyoto and you can see all the way to Osaka if it is a clear day.
There's an entry fee to Shogunzuka and you don't want to stay there too late as they close the cemetary gates in the evening and the last bus goes at like 18:00 IIRC.

It's supposed to be a decent airline, and it's just taking advantage of how airlines put surcharges on fuel that make up the bulk of the cost of tickets. It's sort of an error where the last flight causes the tickets to drop all fuel surcharges, leaving only the base cost of the ticket. Finding the third flight that causes this is a huge challenge and puzzle, however. You also have to find initial flights where the base cost is low and has ticket stipulations that allow for it to occur to begin with.

This is a short explanation if you want to learn more: https://www.secretflying.com/posts/fuel-dumping-basics/

posts.com: Are there places in Japan where I can still go places as a very introverted/shy person and not look weird? Especially if it's not super crowded like Tokyo or Osaka.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390322
>temples, parks, museums some night life, see the culture
Then you should venture outside the major cities, except for the night life and museum stuff.

I don't know what sort of person you are, but I definitely regretted spending 2 of the 5 weeks I had in Japan in Tokyo (although it was planned as I had a 3 week JR Pass and was stationary for the rest of the time) and too much time in the cities in general but loved my time in smaller cities and the countryside.
Kyoto was the biggest letdown, as the masses of tourists there, especially chinese people and school children made it completely unenjoyable, at least for me.

Considering you're going to Fuji/Osaka, are you getting a JR pass? Do you just want to be near Mt Fuji and look at it or actually hike it (the latter isn't possible in April afaik)?
If you're gonna make the trip there and to Osaka, there's a few things I would recommend in the "viccinity" (some closer, some farther).
Nara is really nice and slightly less overrun than Kyoto in my experience, although I don't know how it'll be in April (cherry blossom season).
Himeji is also nice, mainly for the castle, and probably less crowded.
Matsumoto and the Japanese Alps (Kamikochi) are absolutely amazing if you're into the outdoors/mountains.
If you want to go a bit further, Hiroshima was my favorite bigger city by far and hiking Mt Misen on Miyajima is not only a great trip but takes you away from the masses in the town/shrine area.

If you do have a JR pass and want to travel a bit, I would also recommend making a trip towards Tohoku from Tokyo. Nikko, Matsushima and Yamadera were some of my favorite places of the entire trip.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2390272
>>2390417
How fluent are you in Japanese because if you are fluent and want to eat food at mom and pop restaurants favored by locals, just watch the live action TV drama of Kodoku no Gourmet, which features real life Japanese restaurants. It is a very popular TV drama in Japan that is responsible for increasing foot traffic to the restaurants mentioned by the show and is already on its tenth season!

However, don't worry if you are not fluent in Japanese, because a quick Google search reveals websites hosting episodes with English subtitles.

Kodoku no Gourmet (孤独のグルメ, "Solitary Gourmet") is a Japanese cuisine seinen manga series written by Masayuki Qusumi and illustrated by Jiro Taniguchi. It has been adapted into a Japanese television drama series

The Solitary Gourmet (Kodoku no Gurume) is about a man who eats alone. That’s it. The show follows the life of Gorō Inogashira (played by Yutaka Matsushige), a middle-aged tableware salesman, who in each episode has some brief interaction with the world around him — a discussion about renting new office space, a meeting with an over-talkative woman who wants to buy teacups — but after no more than 10 minutes of this troublesome interaction with other people, his stomach starts growling, and the rest of the show is devoted to his thoughts as he eats alone.

The beauty of The Solitary Gourmet comes not just in the foods that Gorō eats, but in his face as he eats them. This is a man who always looks slightly stricken. When he speaks out loud, it tends to be hesitant and stilted. But as he eats, even if his expression is serious, in voiceover we hear his inner thoughts as he deeply enjoys the food he’s been served. This is a man whose one true joy is dining alone, but we get to share his meals with him.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kodoku_no_Gourmet

https://twitter.com/tx_kodokugurume

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EllpGKKIsec

>>2390488
In February you’ll probably get cold in the morning and night. It’s pretty chilly in Tokyo right now since it’s been raining for a few hours, but this week has been surprisingly mild for January during the day. Get a heavy jacket and wear it on the plane. Consider gloves and high socks as well (I mildly regret not bringing high socks). Learn the subway lines before you go. Which lines go to which stations etc… It’s not very hard to wing it but I wish I had the knowledge before jumping in. A word of advice: the Keiyo line transfer at Tokyo Station is a nightmare. You’re better off walking to/from Tokyo Station if you’re staying around the Hatchobori Station area unless it’s raining.

You could grab up to 100,000 yen (per day) directly at an (airport) exchange, on some service's website their rates are nearly 1:1 to market, but I'd guess that a service cost of ~2% would come on top. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390939
Try purposefully choosing your starting train destination to be one of the JR stations/lines and see if the route isn't too different on time/efficiency. For example, if I am in Osaka I can often use the JR Osaka Loop and its supported stations instead of the other local lines, and the difference might just be a few minutes slower, but the trip would be free. Or in Tokyo if you want to make round trips between Tokyo and someplace nearby like Kawasaki. But the bulk of the potential savings does come from Shinkansen rides. I covered the cost of a 2-week pass with trips between Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Hiroshima, and the extra savings on the local JR lines also made the pass worth it. If it's your first time visiting and you're not comfortable enough to deviate from what Google Maps recommends to a tee, then it's less useful.

>>2391312
Ignore >>2391324 >>2391349, they don't know what they're talking about. The JR pass is usually not worth it. Use the JR pass website to estimate your costs https://www.japan-guide.com/railpass/ . Remember, it is far cheaper (and often faster) to fly than take the train.
For example, >>2391349 said the price of a 7day JR pass is roughly the same as a roundtrip Shinkansen ticket to Osaka ($230). But did not mention you can fly from Tokyo-Osaka for literally 1/3rd the price ($70 round trip tickets on google flights right now), or take the bus for $25 (it does take 8 hours).
JR pass is a meme and people exaggerate its benefits. The primary benefit is convenience (hop on / hop off trains), not monetary.
>>2391324 is telling you to buy a $550 21-day train pass of which you'll use at most $200 of its value. Don't do that.
>>2391349 claims "You need to order your JR pass well in advance" which is not true at all, you can buy them at any major JR station in Japan. Note, the online price is 4000 yen cheaper.
>>2391349 also claims "the pass grants you quite literally 90% Free travel in Tokyo" which is utter bullshit, the JR pass only covers travel on JR lines and 80% of the subway lines in Tokyo are not run by JR. See pic related - every subway line on that map is *not* covered by JR. You literally can't get around on only JR lines.

To answer your questions
* Yes, you can buy a JR pass in japan at any of these stations https://japanrailpass.net/en/exchange.html .
* With or without a JR pass, you can buy tickets / reserve seats at the train station the day of your trip. You can use the machine (it supports english), or talk to the person at the counter. Show up around 20 mins before your train departs. There is no rush, I have reserved tickets literally 5 mins before my train departed.

>>2390764
Fix your itinerary. Just spend 6 nights in Osaka and it will make your life much easier. Kyoto and Nara are both daytrip-able from Osaka. There is an express train between Umeda station <-> Kyoto station that takes 35min. It costs 1500 yen. For Nara, there is a direct train from Umeda station that costs 800 yen. It takes 1 hour. Staying in Osaka the entire time means you do not have to carry your luggage around, and also you can rearrange days depending on your needs.
When you are done with Osaka, you can forward your luggage from Osaka -> Tokyo for about 2500yen.
One suggestion for you: If you are flying into Narita, consider flying from NRT -> KIX rather than taking the NRT->shinkansen->Osaka. It's cheaper, and will save you 2 hours travel time.

Attached is the map of JR lines in Tokyo. Compared to the map I shared in >>2391440, the breadth is not comparable.
Furthermore, justifying that the pass is worth it because it "grants you quite literally 90% Free travel in Tokyo" is moronic considering a 7-day JR pass costs 4000 yen per day, and there's no way in hell you will spend that much per day on JR while staying in Tokyo. Limiting ourselves to JR lines, Shinjuku to Akihabara is 170yen. A longer day-trip Shinjuku to Yokohama is only 570yen. A full day trip to Shinjuku-Kamakura is only 940 yen.
Every day you have the JR pass in Tokyo, you pretty much are guaranteed to not cover the cost of the pass. This goes back to my point - before buying the JR pass, put in your itinerary into the JR pass calculator
https://www.japan-guide.com/railpass/ . It pretty much doesn't work out.

Please rate my itinerary. I am traveling with my elderly parents and younger, college-aged brother in the early summer. I convinced my father not to book a tour bus group and instead allow me to plan the daily events and book the hotels.

Days 1-5) Arrive in Osaka late in the afternoon, get to the hotel, fall asleep. Spend the next two days getting over jet-lag by wandering the city. Daytrip to Himeji on day 4. Daytrip to Kobe on day 5.

Days 6 and 7) Take a train to Kinosaki and stay at a ryokan. Chill at the hot springs all day.

Days 8-12) Travel to Kyoto. Spend the first night there doing nothing of interest (dad can't handle too much excitement). Go temple hopping on days 9 and 10; I definitely want to check out the cricket temple. Daytrip to Nara on day 11. Daytrip to Miyama on day 12.

Day 13) Go back to Osaka and get ready to fly back home. Nothing planned.

Day 14) Peace out.

I appreciate all suggestions on how I can improve this itinerary before I start booking hotels.

>>2391878
No, it's bad in comparison to many other places. Staying in akihabara is kinda dumb, imo you do 1 or 2 days there and you've seen everything. It's actually kinda mid as far as Tokyo districts go, and I'm saying that as an anime fan. I only went there twice in my 3 weeks in Tokyo, and I only went the second as I was searching for some very niche figures. It isn't even special when it comes to arcades either, there's good (and probably better) arcades all across Tokyo.

Shibuya and Shinjuku are GOAT for nightlife (shibuya better imo but thats cause I'm a young guy who likes nightclubs), and Ueno is peak for great daytime activities, with so many museums just in Ueno park alone. The Ueno area also just worth wandering around.

Also worth visiting is the Edo-Tokyo open air architectural museum and the Edo-Tokyo museum, but iirc the latter is closed for renovations. I cannot recommend it enough if you come back to Japan though, focuses a lot on the firebombing and earthquakes to the extent it gave me vibes similar to the 9/11 memorial in NYC, with a similar quality (just an overall very well put together museum experience, my fave from Tokyo for sure). I'm excited to see it post renovation since I'm moving to tokyo long term in September.

There's just so much to do in Tokyo and Yokohama. Once you go to Japan you'll probably realize that anime and arcades is actually one of the LEAST exciting things about Japan. So much history and culture all over the place. What I've recommended here only scratches the surface.

Try and reduce the constant hotel switching.
For example, stay in Kanazawa for 4 days and travel to Takayama for a daytrip from Kanazawa.

Same for Kyoto/Osaka/Hiroshima. Just get up early one morning and take the shinkansen to Hiroshima for a daytrip.

With the exception of the Northwestern part of the state near Erie, the weather isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The Philadelphia area gets more sun but it gets pretty hot and humid in spring and summer. The Pittsburgh area tends to be overcast, wet, and snowy, mild in spring and summer. Everywhere else is somewhere in between the two. The "mountains" (big hills) run from Southwest to Northeast. East of the mountains gets Mid-Atlantic currents and West of the mountains gets some lake effect from the Great Lakes. Property values vary so much across the state. All of the areas I mentioned are deteriorating less than elsewhere in the state. Philly has a lot of crime, but as I said, it's really the only U.S. city comparable to Chicago or New York.

>>2382956
Amherst native here, just got back from spending Christmas in the area. I agree that it’s got a hell of a lot going for it for a relatively small town, but would argue that nearby Northampton has a better and more walkable downtown core. I have a midsized gang of childhood friends who either stayed in or returned to the area, and nearly all of them drive all the time; those who don’t are mostly hardcore bicyclists.

Desirable housing can also be expensive relative to local incomes—people I know who have bought homes in the area recently have ended up in Hadley (mostly not at all walkable) and Easthampton (only a few central walkable square blocks), or farther out into the (decidedly non-walkable) hilltowns, rather than being comfortably able to afford either Amherst or Noho. Perhaps rents for the new construction apartments in downtown Amherst aren’t bad, though; I dunno.

>>2382821
I had a good time in Madison, Wisconsin, when I went to grad school there. The central isthmus is dense and walkable, and less-central neighborhoods are mostly bikeable. And it wasn’t terribly expensive when I lived there (cheaper than MA), but I assume there are many more expensive new condo/apartment developments downtown that could have driven COL/rents up. So depending on where you are now it might or might not be affordable. But it’s not big-city expensive despite almost feeling like a city.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2391482
This may not be a direct answer but I did trading (stock, options, etc) back around 2005-6 and I did it from several places, not just Europe. Did the meme 'trading from the beaches of Thailand' for a few months. I had enough cushion with money to the point where I could go pretty much wherever I wanted...not a huge cushion, but enough. Back then, the internet wasn't the best in all first world places, never mind the third world.
My advice is if you can do everything via internet, I would travel as much as possible. Its fun, and you won't regret doing it. The hard part obviously is getting the job....from my travels prior to Covid, my experience is that the internet is actually pretty good in most places, but you actually may have to fend off rolling electrical blackouts as a bigger problem.
The one big problem I remember was the time difference for trading...not sure if that would be a problem in your case.
If you ever do find a fully remote job, take a week long trip to somewhere like Ireland or Germany to get your feet wet with overseas problems and go from there!
Good luck!

>>2391596
I've done both,

Precovid my job was my company sending me all kinds of places for work. While it is/was fun, the bigger problem is that you're almost always under someones magnifying glass. It's always stupid shit too like, "Gee anon I see you're not booked to fly out after you're done at X location, why?" or "No anon you need to be at X on monday, so you can't stay in Y city for the rest of the week/next few days". Usually accommodations are paid and with the right company you can bank to your personal accounts. Far better on the wallet, but your time can be easily shafted.

Since 2018 My job has been nearly entirely project based so I can basically pull ass 1-3 days then fuck off other than responding to the occasional email here or there. I have to fork out more cash, assure my boss(not that he cares) that I am getting all my shit done wherever I am in the world, but have the most freedom. The gotcha' is that unlike being set to places for work I can be in some place like this summer when I was in Finland but work decided BIG FUCKING PROJECT took up my weeks there kinda fucking me out of a lot of exploration. If I had my prior 'work sends me to place' once 5PM hits I am out for the day or know well ahead of time my hours.

Neither is better or worse than the other imo, but grass will always be greener.

>>2384884
I think you misunderstand the entire suburb conversation.

It isn't about the fact that edges of cities will have predominantly residential zoning, it's that in America (and this stretches into Canada) we have the phenomenon of developer corporations (e.g. Mattamy homes) creating fake suburban neighbourhoods from scratch in a specific, awful way. This involves dumping cookie-cutter single-family houses, all of the same design, with zero utilities or commercial/retail/industrial space within walking distance. This creates essentially an open-air prison entirely dependent on the urban metropolis for support. You may see my original post for a photographic example.

Compare with a landscape where there is no globohomo developer corporation mass-building suburbs - i.e. continental Europe. In these suburbs, each land lot is owned by a separate property owner who builds his own house or industrial/commercial space.This flexibility allows for a flourishing of industry (in picrel, of suburbs of Kraków, you can see at least 3 separate businesses) and encourages self-sufficiency and a feeling of natural rootedness. And of course, this creates uniqueness in that every property is just a little bit different from its neighbour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

I don't know which big casino, if any, will have such a low table minimum, but the good news is that the minimums are posted conspicuously so that you don't accidentally end up at the $100 table.

Blackjack is easy and fun (as long as you know how to add). The best part is that you're only ever playing against the house rather than other players, like you would in poker. There's a ton of websites out there that show you how to play, you just have to pick one and roll with it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2388898
Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

Oh boy, yes I've got some memories in that place. Storytime:

>a while ago, several years before Fukushima nuclear disaster
>be me, 20yo weeb studying Jap in Tokyo
>holidays at my language school, bored af
>"hey anon, don't you like Ghibli? Did you know Miyazaki went to this island called Yakushima where he got inspired to make princess mononoke? maybe you can check it out, you can hike and shit"
>yeah that sounds dope
>never hiked in my life
>go to the Victoria outdoor goods store on the main road between Jimbocho and Ogawamachi stations
>spend a buttload of money on gourmet camping food because I don't want to starve in Yakushima island
>instant truffle risottos, dehydrated mutton ragu, all the fanciest food imaginable
>pick up a folding stove and gas canisters, venom extraction kits, basically enough supplies to last through the apocalypse
>pass a bicycle store on the way home
>see a cool looking folding bicycle
>hey this might come in useful, like how else would I get to the trail entrance from wherever the bus drops me off (spoiler - the bus drops you off directly at the trail entrance)
>get the bike, ride it home
>look in my wallet, realize I've just spent nearly all the money I have left for that month
>realize I didn't buy an actual backpack to carry all my stuff, proper shoes for hiking or hiking pants
>barely have enough money left for the train and ferry tickets to actually get to Yakushima from Tokyo
>fuck it, guess I'll wing it
>throw everything in a gym shoulder duffel bag type thing
>get my gym shoes, tshirt and swimming shorts because hey it's probably gonna get hot down there
>I'm ready to climb the summit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>next day go to train station and get a shinkansen ticket to Kagoshima, big coastal town from which ferries to Yakushima depart
>end up leaving the stupid folding bicycle at home because duffel bag is heavy enough as it is with all the instant risottos and gas canisters, can barely walk if I've got the folded bike in the other hand
>train trip to Kagoshima takes basically the whole day
>stay the night at a cheap Japanese inn type place, owned by a quirky Jap dude who's really into radios, first floor is basically his workshop with 1000s of radios and components
>next morning get myself a rice ball and little bottled green tea
>jump on the ferry to Yakushima
>on the Yakushima side there is an information office
>konnichiwa, I want to climb to the top of Yakushima
>cute staff lady looks a little concerned
>"here, please fill out this form indicating which day you plan to be at which camp sites and when you return let us know you're alive otherwise we have to send out a search party for you"
>don't worry I got this
>they give me some maps and tell me which bus to get on
>winding mountain road, 20 minutes to the trailhead
>everyone dressed pretty normal, no backpacks, don't know what oneesan was so worried about
>get off the bus and go through the entrance, start going up the trail
>spectacular scenery, every corner is teeming with life
>not even 10 minutes in and there are little deer crisscrossing the path
>butterflies the size of my hand
>deafening choruses of cicadas
>boulders covered by an inch of lush green moss that look like they would start moving any moment

>my exposed sweaty pasty gaijin legs are an object of intrigue to the insect life
>get to a rest site where families are chilling out, everyone having a good time
>spot a sign off to the side leading further into the mountain
>this must be my path

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>keep climbing on

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Glenstone Museum in Potomac, Maryland.

It is a private contemporary and modern art museum funded and built by this massively wealthy couple, and it just fuckin nails it. It has a fantastic blend of interior and exterior spaces, scenic walks with sculpture gardens, cheeky surprises, and rooms built singularly to display one piece of art and then completely renovated and changed if the time comes to display something new. The best part is that admission is very limited, so you never ever feel like you are part of the masses of people. The architecture of the museum buildings and the landscaping make it so that the experience very intentionally brings you into pavilions where you will see other people, and then moves you to outdoor sculpture gardens where you'll be the only one there. Just top to bottom an incredible museum.

Honorable mentions for US art museums go to the Getty, MET, MoMA, NGA, Phillips Collection, deCordova, Minneapolis Institute of Art, The Art Institute, and probably a couple I'm forgetting.

>>2386164
The football museum in Tokyo - good exhibit on the world cup and other exhibits and bits and pieces on football not just in Japan but the world.
The Chester Beatty Library in Dublin - more a mix of different items than an exact museum but still pretty well stocked with a variety of art, texts etc.
Both Autoworld in Brussels and Louwman in The Hague - both car museums, one a pretty short visit and the other massive, but both have interesting sets of cars. Autoworld has a mix of different decades (even cars used by the Nazi regime) and Louwman has mainly older cars at first but then goes into a lot of racing cars. They're also sister museums along with museums in the UK, Italy and France.
Imperial War Museum/Churchill War Rooms, London - excellent recreation of the war rooms from the WW2.
Currency Museum of the Bank of Japan, Tokyo - what got me into the idea of going to similar museums abroad, extensive history of currency in the country (which went through multiple stages) and also features a look at notable foreign currencies. You can get a guide in English. Also completely free.
Louvre, Paris - it's well known but there's a depth to it with plenty of historical artefacts from multiple empires. Not just a place for paintings.
Olympic museum, Barcelona - very linear and a short visit but worth a look if you go up to the Olympic Stadium.
Football Museum, Manchester - you can tell they wanted to create the biggest football museum with everything and anything because, well, it is.
Museu de la Xocolata, Barcelona - very informative on the origins of chocolate in Europe and has some really nice recreations made from chocolate. I know plenty of cities have their equivalent but while this one is short, it's better than the rest. It also sells some really nice cocoa powder that makes some really thick drinking chocolate.
Museum Dräi Eechelen – Fort Thüngen, Luxembourg - if you're in the city then it's probably the best museum there
Can also second >>2386179

>>2387597
>>Any recommendations or personal expriences to share?
I live in Europe and have visited many hundreds of places here on the subcontinent; I might have suggestions if could be more specific about where you’re going. I find most of Northern Europe (esp. Scandinavia) overpriced and not very interesting, Germany agreeably affordable but mostly dull, with forgettable food, the Mediterranean more relaxed and enjoyable, as well as being cheap (most things in Iberia or Italy or Greece or even southern France should be noticeably less expensive than NZ), etc. Some of the most-hyped, most touristed cities are actually still great (haters gonna freak out, but I unapologetically enjoy Paris, Barcelona, Florence, London, and others), many of the resort areas are indeed almost nothing but fake British pubs and drunken yobs and ugly modern condo complexes but can still be enjoyed with the right mindset. The Balkans are gritty and cheap and often a lot of fun. Coastal Croatia is intolerably overcrowded in the high season but still very beautiful. Etc.
>Are the chicks easy over there?
Varies a lot. Probably about as easy as Kiwi women on average, which is to say that some will sleep with you and some won’t. Some countries are noticeably more conservative (Catholic, rural Mediterranean, poorer Balkan countries, anywhere Muslim), some relatively uninhibited (Scandies, Netherlanders, about half of the Slavs).
>How much should I save
Hard to advise without an itinerary. South is cheaper than at home, Nordics probably more expensive, Switzerland definitely more expensive.
>Anything I should know before going?
Don’t be an asshole.

>>2387669
Hmmm… I assume you are flying into Frankfurt? It’s really not a tourist city at all, no reason I can think of to visit. I guess a poster above speaks highly of their brothels? Not my scene, so beats me, but they probably have hookers in Dresden, too, which is more interesting than Frankfurt for a visitor.

I also see a lot of Swiss cities; some posters here like to scream about the fact that Swiss cities are all trash and the only reason to visit this country (I live here) is to see the mountains and countryside. I think this take is almost psychotic in its overkill, but will say that Zürich isn’t very interesting for a tourist, while being startlingly expensive. Luzern is a bit nicer as a tourist town; if you go, be sure to take some boat trips on the enormous lake. Might be worth considering swapping Zürich for Bern (many posters here hate Bern, too, but I think its historic center is prettier than Zürich’s) and adding a side trip somewhere in the nearby mountains of the Bernese highlands. I like the whole region around Lake Thun. The town of Thun is really nice, and there are some interesting thousand-year-old churches in villages around the lake that can be reached by boat. Most Swiss hate Interlaken, but it does have relatively cheap tourist infrastructure for stuff like hiking and paragliding, and the geographical setting is pretty.

I like Geneva myself, but almost none of my Swiss friends can stand it—it’s an extremely international city, almost a company town for the UN with a side of banks and watches. Most people recommend Lausanne instead.

You probably already know that there is nothing at all in Liechtenstein; the whole country is like a minor Swiss suburb. Fine as a novelty visit if you’re passing through from/to Austria, but not worth more than a couple of hours.

Lake Como is beautiful but Lago Maggiore is similar and a bit cheaper. Milan has its lovers and haters but I think it’s OK.

> Sounds like tourism in Switzerland is a pain due to it not being part of the EU?
It’s not difficult to travel in, and it’s still part of the Schengen area, so there are no border controls with the EU, it’s just really expensive and arguably offers not much you can’t get for cheaper from our neighbors. It’s also not a food destination compared with Italy or France, for what it’s worth, although the cheese and chocolate are both top-notch.

Germans and Italians like to use cash, but plastic is fine almost everywhere in Switzerland. I rarely carry much cash when I travel in Europe.

>What do you think of Zermatt? I know it's expensive, but I don't mind paying more for quality. I want to snowboard, drink beer and eat cheese and sausage.

Zermatt has the iconic Matterhorn views and is generally pretty nice, but I never go there—I take my winter holidays in either Canton Bern (Grindelwald, or other Jungfrau region sites; Wengen is arguably even more picturesque than Zermatt) or Graubünden (Laax/Flims/Falera for me, although friends also like Arosa and Davos).

>If I fly in and out of Geneva, are there any better options in Switzerland than Zermatt?

Zermatt is actually pretty far from Geneva; there are several closer (and less expensive, and arguably as good or better) ski resorts in France, most famously probably Chamonix. The places I mention in Canton Bern are also not much farther away from Geneva than Zermatt is. But better is relative and totally subjective.

>>2388302
>Any recommendations for Geneva? Food?
Geneva is good for fancy French-style cooking (albeit not quite as good as France, and at a bit of a Swiss premium), more down-home Italian and Portuguese food (for as little as 3X what it would cost in Italy or Portugal), and international cuisines--it's about as good as it gets in Switzerland for Asian restaurants, for example. L'Aparte is Michelin starred, modern French, and has really nice tasting menus for not much more than CHF100. The Paquis neighborhood is good for a wide range of cheap-and-cheerful ethnic places. The old city isn't that great for food--a lot of overpriced Swiss restaurants aimed mostly at tourists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
I appreciate the help, i want some hardcore shit, i have all these thoughts of dying already and its a month till my flight, idk i never take any medication or pills of any kind, but im close to cancelling my flight out of fear and i need the assurance i can get something that will make me knock out for 10 hours. I appreciate the advice, i need to go see a doctor ASAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

>I heard they have the worse return tourist rate (5%) of the SEA countries. Why don't tourists return to Vietnam?
1. Most people who would do return trips after crossing off all the major sights from their list are either sex pests or resort tourists. Vietnam is garbage for both. The cooming offer is nowhere close to its neighbors and the beaches are frankly shit. While they can seem nice at a first glance, Vietnam is drowning in trash and has zero water pollution standards. You'll be frolicking in the waves and suddenly there's literal shit all around you.
2. People are often plain rude. There's little in the way of etiquette and the concept of disturbing others (which is generally a problem with SEA, but not to that level) does not exist in Vietnam at all. They'll spit, cut the line and play shitty Tik-Tok vids on full volume at 3AM on a night bus if they feel like it. Everyone working in the tourist industry has nothing but utmost contempt for tourists and will make sure you know that.
3. Scams. 80% of all Vietnamese you'll interact with will lie through their teeth in an attempt to extract money from you. If you don't play along, they'll get loud, insistent and aggressive. You can easily get ripped off in Thailand, which has ten times the return rate, but they usually do it with a smile and try to make sure you won't notice. Vietnam is on the level of people blatantly telling you to fuck off and demanding double while you point at the price list right behind them.
Don't take me wrong, Vietnam's my favorite place in SEA, but it is, without any doubt, a rude shithole that is the very opposite of comfy and that relaxed holiday feeling is what people are usually looking for.

posts.com:
Serious answer:

I found that Vietnam doesn't really have much to do for a tourist as far as big sites are concerned, and what they do have is very spread out. The attraction to Vietnam is mostly the entire country itself, the hostel culture and vibe was good but I don't think that gets people to come back, I enjoyed Vietnam but wouldn't return because I feel like I got everything I needed out of it.

Big tourist sites are Phong Nha Caves, Ha Long bay, Hai Van pass, Ha Giang loop, a few museums in Hanoi and Saigon. All of these are hundreds of miles apart and the transportation in the country is slow as fuck to get anywhere. It's not like Europe where you can show up in a capitol and have tons to do.

Also the English proficiency in the country sucks, the only people who could speak English were hostel workers and some extremely tourist focused restaurants in Hanoi. I went to large international catering hotels where they had 1 receptionist there who could barely speak any English, obviously I don't expect every rice farmer on the side of the road to speak perfect English but when nobody can it isn't good for tourists.

t. Spent 1 month in Vietnam, motorcycled Saigon to Hanoi

Yes, but it's ass. Every single bit of info you'll find on the web is utterly useless because Viets shut down everything for the memeflu, then re-opened only half of it and changed the details of the routes and schedules without posting them anywhere.
For example, you'll find old posts on the web that there's a convenient bus number 1 that goes from Da Nang center to Hoi An. Then you'll find plenty of people saying it does not exist any more post-COVID and you're stuck with Grab/taxi.
The truth is it actually does but nobody knows about it, you have to take a bus to the Viet Han terminus station at some college in the South of the city, then wait an unspecified amount of time (count an hour at least) for the Bus 1 to arrive. It will then kick you out ~2km outside of Hoi An proper because it doesn't go to the center of either town anymore.
This shit will happen to you constantly. You arrive somewhere expecting it to be doable by public transport, only to find out you're stuck because nothing works as advertised and all your research was bullshit. Keep in mind you can't even ask the locals for assistance because every single one of them will shout "NO BUS" and try to sell you the services of their taxi driver nephew.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386479
The major bus routes (the numbered ones within Hanoi and Saigon) are all running, and they have schedules available on google maps. If you are at the starting point of the bus line (say, the airport or a bus station), that particular departure time on the schedule might even be accurate.
Between the cities (unnumbered buses with written destinations), it's still pretty wild. Be flexible and leave early. I find the local transportation network here (outside cities) to be about as reliable as Thailand's, for better or worse.

On a separate note (don't want to gift any of the trolls with a >you), Vietnam is an amazing country, with friendly people who genuinely like tourists and expats. There are very few sexpats, and very few Vietnamese who seethe about sexpats. No one here hates Americans, most are indifferent about Chinese, and they see everyone else as just everyone else.

>>2386838
>Thanks for your answer but I still can't get it so how can I roam around for example in hanoi to see stuff which is worth to see?
Decide what you want to see and use Google Maps to see how to get there. If it's within a km and in central Hanoi, you'll probably get there fastest by walking. For longer distances, you can use Grab bike (motorbike taxis). Switch to the transit option of Google Maps to see if there are buses going where you want to go. Or use Grab car (car taxis). It's pretty simple once you try.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386851
>depends on the city, in Hanoi buses are ok
>in Saigon drivers are retarded and don't even stop at bus stops, buses usually stop operating very early, around 7-8pm
I find buses in both cities are good. Some of the Saigon buses run until 1am. Unlike Hanoi, you will need to wave at the drivers to get them to pick you up because the stops serve multiple lines and the driver won't stop if it looks like nobody wants his line. This is the same in much of SEA in my experience - Hanoi is really an exception to this.
>in smaller cities it may be really difficult to find information about the routes if the buses even exists
Very true. You often need to go to the bus station and ask. They'll tell you the schedule, and it's often posted at the bus station, but good luck if you wander across a rural bus stop outside a town and you want to know when (or if) the next one will show up. Inside a town, just ask at the nearby businesses using Google translate.

>>2378355
Vietnamese society is not very competitive. If you read the Hofstede cultural dimensions assessment of Vietnam, you will see that Vietnam is considered a feminine society where there is no strong emphasis on achievement and competition. This isn't to say that the Vietnamese do not value achievements. But compared to the far more masculine societies of Japan, China, the US, Canada, Germany, the UK, competition in Vietnam is far less intense than that in the aforementioned countries, particularly Japan which ranks very high in masculinity in the Hofstede cultural framework.

Less competition translates to less stress. This is why working in Vietnam can be great for people who are not too ambitious and are not willing to work hard.

posts.com:
You can find a lot of information/guides on Google desu but I'll try to answer your questions.
>how do i find a good place to live
Lots of websites like booking.com or hostel world can help you find a place, although some would argue you might get better deals on websites directly. I wouldn't stress too much unless you're desperately trying to save money.
>how do i learn important customs in the place i visit/how do i not act retarded.
Again, google can help you. Wikivoyage usually has some tips but there are lots of websites.
>How do i plan my stay?
Look at websites like wikivoyage, lonely planet, tripadvisor etc. Make a list of must do things and some optional stuff if you gave time. Don't over plan it, you should be able to be spontaneous, you never know what might come up. In terms of time, I typically plan 3 or 4 nights per place I'm staying - it can be more or less based on how much time I estimate I'll need.
>then there are also issues like transport
Again, you'll need to use resource websites like wikivoyage. If you're interested in Japan, the Japan general thread has resources in the OP.
Also, not to overwhelm you, but don't forget to look into visa requirements.

If you check the archives, recently there was a thread where the OP lost his phone. I didn't keep up with the thread but perhaps there's some useful information in that thread. Some suggestions I do have is to bring 2 phones and 2 wallets. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
>how to travel i have no idea wtf im doing
First thing's first, what's your budget (how much are you willing to spend total - $3000, $4000)? If you can't afford it then you can't go. Second, where are you going and for how long? You can split your budget by number of days and then check if you have enough money for accomodations, food, tourism, flight, transportation or if it will be unafforadble for you at which point you need to work more and delay your trip. You're from EU so that passport should open a lot of doors for you, some countries may still require you to apply for a visa so check before you buy a ticket if you need to or don't. Also, check restrictions on time limits for visa-free travel (can't go in visa free and stay indefinitely, many places have a 90 day limit).
>what about a place to stay?
hostels, airbnb's, cheap hotels, expensive hotels are all options. You want to focus on WHERE you want to stay. Staying "in tokyo" is not the same as staying "in akihabara in tokyo", you could be a massive distance apart from where you want to realistically spend most of your time. Look for accommodations within your budget in a zone you like, or just next to the zone you want to be in if it's not too far (or if public transport is close, available and reliable).
>what about customs?
dont need to know them for the most part, just know big ones (i.e. no alcohol in muslim countries, no drugs practically anywhere, no nudity in the streets) and just be polite. If you dress well and are polite, no one will bother you, if you fuck up a custom that people care for just apologize and ask for an explanation after telling them you didnt know. What you should know is that if strangers approach you for something, 99% chance its a scam. Strangers will help you, but usually only after YOU ask THEM for help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391466 (cont.)
>how do i plan my stay?
Research, and lots of it. You have the internet available, so use it. You can go minimalist and winging it or you can make a full day by day itinerary where you pick certain stops per day and plan a route to visit all of them. If you search online you may find sample routes for places you want to go to which you can alter at will based on your own interests. Look up lists of landmarks, museums, historical sites, hidden gems, hot spots in town and then find out which ones you want to go to and which ones you can skip on. Once you know where to go, find ways to connect them. If they're all in a circle around your accommodation, divide that circle into quadrants and explore it in a loop so you hit your interests and see the town on the way to and back. You can even find quality restaurants ahead of time per area and go to those the day you head out. It's really no different from mapping out a day in your own town. Something like:
>want to go see city hall in my small town
>oh and there's a museum a few blocks away
>there's even a really beautiful park further down from the museum
>it's going to be around lunchtime when I go, theres a restaurant with great reviews between the museum and park so i can stop there
>after the park i'll need to make my way back, but ill return in a circle instead of a straight line back to check out a church and another museum before I leave
It's that simple, people really overestimate planning for travel. It takes a few hours at most to have everything ready, from bookings to day-to-day itineraries.

Speaking of bookings, do not use sites that book for you. Always book directly with an airline/hotel. If there's a problem and you book directly, then the place that fucked you has to deal with you themselves. If a booking agency fucks up, then you don't deal with the hotel or airline, you deal with the agency, which means you're fucked because they won't give you a fix when you need it, only after.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391399
>how fucked if i lose my phone?
About as fucked as you'd be if you lost your phone right now. Maybe slightly more if you need it for uber or flight info, but nothing you can't fix by borrowing a computer and a printer which most hotels will let you do if you explain the emergency.
>lost hotel room key
most of those are literally a card so they'll just print another one for you at the front desk on request. So literally just don't be a retard. You realistically only need your phone and wallet with you when you go out, both of which fit in your two front pockets and make it very hard for pickpockets to access. If you're worried about losing your phone, ask for a physical map and have the hotel circle their location so you can show that to a cab driver.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
don't worry too much about it man I'm 20 years old myself and just came back from a trip to Costa Rica. If you head to East Asia, Japan would definitely be the best for beginners, followed by Korea, then China. I haven't been to Japan/Korea myself but I can say with a fair amount of certainty that China would be a little difficult for your first trip and there's more than enough to do in Japan itself to worry about it. If you're on a budget and don't want to blow thousands of dollars on accomodation use hostelworld and stay in a hostel. You'll meet other people roughly your age and solo traveling as well so you can do stuff with them. One thing that other people haven't mentioned is that the moment you arrive you want to go find a SIM card. It's usually not too expensive and I've never paid more than 15 bucks for one, but this way you'll get access to local data without raping your current data plan by using roaming data. Good luck man and just do it, don't let yourself back out because you're too apprehensive to click the button.

>>2391137
> I know i would be completely fucked if i bought an airline ticket today and winged it
What makes you say that? It's not hard to 'wing it'. The only things you really need to make sure of are:
>Visa requirements
Just google Japan entry requirements for UK citizen or wherever you're from
>Money + money exchange access
I recommend opening a wise account, it's just a debit card you send money to that can pay in 99% of currencies with very low fees (like 0.5%). Avoid using your home debit card, it's probably going to charge a whole lot more than you expect. Using wise card at the ATM is a good idea too, since cash exchanges charge stupid fees.
>Somewhere to stay on your first night out of the airport
Well, you simply don't want to be caught with nowhere to stay.

That's it. You're going to Japan and Korea, both very safe countries, there's no secret shit you need to learn. There are no secret cultural customs you should learn. You're (probably) a white guy, the japs aren't expecting you to know which side of the road to walk on.

>>2391714
>I'll most likely be in Tokyo for the whole 30 days
I get that tokyo is a massive city, but you'd be missing out. Japan has a renowned train network, it wouldn't be hard to get to other places, I'm sure there are a lot of great places outside of tokyo that you can get to easily. You definitely shouldn't try to do a whole tour of Japan with 10 cities in only 2 weeks, but 30 days is a very long time for a single place.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2391749
On top of this, and most importantly. Allow yourself to be spontaneous.
If you are staying in a hostel (which I highly recommend) and someone invites to do something, it's probably a good idea to go. If someone says there going to some other city and you think it looks like a good place, then you should consider joining them even if it wasn't in your plans. When you're on a holiday you can afford to do that, what else have you got to do, work?
There are two types of people that I HATE when it comes to travelling: picky eaters and over-planners, or people who are too scared to stray from their plan.

Just know where you need to be for your flights, that's important. You might have a few ideas of where you'd like to go, but be flexible, transport and accommodation might not always be in your favour. Or, someone you meet will show you a better location.

Being spontaneous on trips is fun, and it will teach you that every day presents you with millions of decisions, most people don't realise those decisions that they make.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391753
>Worried about people not speaking english
Google translate, just translate no more than 8-10 words at a time and use simplified english, it works better that way.
>I have to figure out public transport on my own
Typically easier than you imagine. I would be surprised if electronic ticket machines at train stations didn't have a button to display in English. Most developed countries have their public transport loaded on google maps, for longer bus rides that require privately owned transport, use rome2rio. A lot of cities have special 'bus card' things, I guarantee you can buy one of these at the airport with $15 pre loaded onto it.
>Aren't hostels expensive
Almost always cheaper than a hotel. I just searched for accommodation in tokyo on booking dot com and sorted by cheapest, the whole first page was all hostels. Besides, the opportunity to meet people by staying in hostels cannot be bought.

My other tip, take a backpack not wheeled luggage.

Basically Anon, you're 20 years old, you don't need the boring boomer-tier holiday where you have a private apartment your travel agent got you. What you need is a wild ride where you make last minute decisions, meet new people, leave them behind, go places you didn't even know existed, try foods you can't pronounce, walk through parts of the city where taxis don't go, have conversations with people you knew for 3 hours yet will remember forever and come back with photos that actually have interesting stories attached to them.
Would you rather show your friends back home a photo of a statue and say "this is just some old statue, I walked there and went home." or be able to say "I met these 2 american guys who were going to see this statue, so went and saw it with them. I really liked those guys, so I went with them to kyoto the next day."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2367779
>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

picrel from a bike trip I took in east-central india earlier this year (sorry for crappy angle, don't have anything better on laptop and too lazy to transfer from phone)

>Athens

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

In Athens the opposite of what is happening in most of the world is happening. Most the world has seen the city center being reclaimed by the rich and the professional yuppie class and their gentrifying, but in Athens the property market is the reverse, the city center is now a dump that is like an Islamic shitstain country and the outer areas of Athens are more expensive and sought after.

Finally this trip I spent much more time in the wealthier sections on the outer perimeter of Athens and the infrastructure still sucks, but it is nothing like the dystopia that is the Athens city center which is a mini Karachi or Dhaka at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373726
Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best
South Lake Tahoe. It's the most gorgeous place Ive ever seen. The lake is insane. Awesome outdoor bars. Amazing bike trails and hikes. But it still has a downtown area with a lot of good food and bars. Sitting around at the Hangar bar drinking beer by the fire at night under the stars is a vibe that's hard to match.

Jackson Hole Wyoming. The food is shockingly good. Every place in town is like a gourmet cowboy bar. You can do pretty much any outdoor outdoor activity. Whitewater rafting the snake river was one of the best experiences of my life. 3 days in Jackson Hole was not enough.

Maui. The best beaches Ive ever seen were in Makena on Maui. We found a condo for $300/night and that was a really good deal. I bought fresh fish a couple times and just grilled out to cut down on the outrageous restaurant bills we racked up. It's insanely expensive and we probably spent 4 grand on a 6 day trip for the 2 of us, but I felt like it was money well spent.

Worst
Portland Oregon. The memes are true. Portland is a homeless cesspool. There were homeless people camped out front of our Airbnb on a normal suburban street. It was one of the least charming cities Ive ever visited.

Atlantic City New Jersey. We parked the car and someone tried to sell us crack within 30 seconds. It's like vegas with none of the attractions but in the worst neighborhood you've ever seen.

Fresno California. You'll probably never go there, because why would you? I had to stay there for a conference. Your nightly choice of dining options are Dominoes Pizza, and a 24 hour McDonalds. It actually has worse crime than LA.There is literally NOTHING to do.

I’ve been to about 80 countries and I don’t think I genuinely hated any. Yeah there are up and downs but I have always found pleasant surprises. Some countries are better than others, for sure. Then there are countries I won’t really come back because I think I did most of it (tiny little ones).

Countries I liked the most:
- Paraguay: the memories of camping and herding cows with Paraguayan equivalent of gauchos in Chaco when I was kid still haunt me to this day.

- Iceland: did a multi-days trek in the middle of nowhere, in snowy volcanic landscape. Nothing is remotely similar.

- Extremadura in Spain, Yunnan in China in the early 00s, Chile, Lake Tahoe in Burgerland, some swampy place in Skåne Sweden (pic rel) etc. Too many things to list.

My latest trip was a road-trip in Netherlands. I liked it, I learned and saw a lot.
I love traveling so much bros.

Rome - So much history and ancient ruins to see there. The city feels like a time capsule and some random back alley pizza shop gave us the best wine I've ever tasted for like 5 euros in a plastic water bottle.

Galway, Ireland - An absolutely gorgeous little town with a lot of culture.

Toronto - Compared to most cities in the US, it's super clean, quiet and feels safe (at least it did 15 years ago when I visited).

Worst:

There were absolutely no redeeming qualities about that place for me.

Paris - kind of a shithole with pickpockets everywhere who target tourists. The base of the Eiffel Tower is covered in Middle Eastern scammers and people aggressively trying to sell you junk. The architecture in the old city is really nice though.

Leeds, UK - was stuck there for six months on study abroad. One of the most boring places I've ever been.

>Best
Hong Kong (pre-2019)
Same energy as Manhattan except perfectly clean and orderly. The ultra-dense 50-story tower blocks, the food, the massive jungle mountains rising out of the ocean, the incomparable views, the fact that you can take a ferry to Lantau Island and be in a remote tropical paradise in 45 minutes, the unique fusion of Chinese and British culture… what an incredible place.

Chicago is underrated but it’s gone waaaaaaaaay downhill since the pandemic and george floyd riots.

>what has changed since 2019?
Forgot to answer this part. First in 2012, then far more substantially in 2019, the Chinese Communist Party forced the Hong Kong government to rewrite large parts of its legal framework (which was supposed to remain untouched until 2047) to align with Chinese law instead of the old British common law. Among other things, HK defendants can now be tried in Mainland China if the CCP demands it. It also purged the HK legislature of anyone who wasn’t fully sympathetic to the CCP.
>I thought they were dropping most of the covid regulations
Nope, just the mandatory quarantine period. Masks are still mandatory, even outside, and they still have a digital vaccine passport system in place with no end date in sight.
