My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?

The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.

Anyone got any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
I'd say 98% yes - the remote IP address they'll see you connecting from will be an IP address belonging to the foreign telco provider. It won't be one of the IP addresses of your home telco provider.
The 2% chance I'm holding back is because I'm aware some telcos do have the options of SIMs with fixed IP addresses tied to them. Without knowing where you are from and what telco you use, I've gotta put that chance as low.
>The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.
I wouldn't put too much weight on this, but you could tell pretty easily by visiting whatsmyip.com while using your SIM abroad and seeing what it says.

There are ways you can get around having a foreign IP address. Others have probably talked about them already, but they come down to using a router or gateway device that can use a VPN. On that device you'd use a VPN (preferably to a friend's home network in your home country, but maybe ExpressVPN will work for you since many of their exit nodes are partnered with local ISPs). Then you connect your work laptop to that router/gateway device. Your work laptop connects to the company VPN and your company VPN sees it coming from the personal/ExpressVPN address your router/gateway is using. If you do this route, you need a router/gateway that with a killswitch that will completely drop your internet interface if the VPN drops.
I think your big problem is having flaky work software that require you to bring the laptop to the office to fix. Maybe get a second work laptop for your "month at the cottage"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
Yeah, they would. International roaming depends on your carrier's agreement with some local carrier to provide you service in order to work. So when you try to log in, it'll show that country's location.

And it's not a guarantee you'll be able to get 5G wherever you go. Even in Europe. I paid my American carrier for unlimited roaming internet while abroad (again, it was a French carrier providing me the actual service, you can only do this a few months before they cut you off anyway), and I bought a French SIM card, and even then, the best I could get was 4G.

Besides that, if your company really is anal about security then there's no way in hell you'll be able to hide the fact that you're abroad from them. The fact that you would even ask this means you aren't technically sophisticated enough to outwit your IT department. You'd only end up getting yourself in trouble.

My advice would be that, if working abroad means that much to you (and I can understand that, because it's a life-changing perk) then I would suggest you look for a job with a company that's willing to look the other way. This means banks and security work are probably a no-go for you (though there are surely exceptions). You should be looking for a new job constantly anyway, so that your compensation is as high as it can be.

Many companies won't allow you to work from abroad, if only to save themselves the tax and legal troubles they would have to figure out in another country. But if you use an American mailing address (say, your parents') and give them plausible deniability, many companies are willing to look the other way to keep valuable employees, including mine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How do you discern when a bribe is necessary? If it is necessary, how does one go about it and what/how much is usually offered?
My first world brain doesn't understand these things, and it would make my life easier while traveling where this is common.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You want to be discreet and avoid incriminating yourself or them by mentioning bribes, though I've had officials straight up tell me they want to get their mom flowers for mother's day so give me money. Ask things like: is there a fine/fee I can pay to resolve this? Can I pay it to you? Can you take care of it for me? Can I pay less, I don't need a receipt? Avoid obviously handing over a bribe, conceal the cash with papers you're handing them or give the official a larger note than what the "official fee" is.

As far as discerning whether a bribe is necessary, and negotiating the bribe amount, that's another subject but the first thing is did you really do something illegal? Not having the right visa paperwork or breaking a traffic law are common opportunities to solicit a bribe. Do you think you should be free to go but they insist you didn't do something right? They're probably looking for a bribe.

I avoid paying bribes. The best way is to just be as patient and insistent as possible and hope the official is lazy and gives up. This works well if they accuse you of something fabricated or trump up the seriousness of something minor that the locals wouldn't get in trouble for like jaywalking. Another option is to insist on calling the "embassy" or ministry of tourism to discuss the problem. This works surprisingly well. But the best advice is to not get yourself into trouble that you need to bribe your way out of, don't bring drugs in, don't get shitfaced in public, etc. And if you have to pay a bribe, start with a low amount, $10 in the third world is more than what most people earn in a day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386763
Coastal Croatia is beautiful, you can go down the coast and stop through all the nice beach towns in homestays (need some Slavic language ability to do this - my family had no issues speaking Slovak). Ended up in Podgora when I went. I've heard that it's become pretty fucked in tourist season though, it's the new beach destination for Western Europeans which pushes the price up and makes it very crowded. I haven't been since 2014 so I haven't seen that first hand.

The rest of this is second-hand, so take with a grain of salt, but all comes from people I know and trust:

Mate of mine just spent a few weeks in Rovinj, coastal town near the Italian border. Cold atm but he said he loved it there. Wasn't impressed with Zagreb.

I've heard from multiple people that Belgrade, Serbia is a really charming city, affordable, good nightlife.

Montenegro has become the new beach destination for the former Eastern Bloc tourists who used to go to Croatia for the summer but got priced out by Western Europeans. Supposedly just as gorgeous as Croatia but cheaper and great hiking.

Lake Ohrid in Macedonia is meant to be beautiful, with an old Byzantine-era monastery somewhere along the shoreline. Pain in the ass to get to apparently.

Avoid the major tourist islands in Greece. They're tourist traps that offer a more expensive version of what you can get on a hundred other lesser-known Greek islands more peacefully.

Just got back from a major trip across the Balkans a few months ago.

Places that I've been...

-Ulcinj, Montenegro
-Budva, Montenegro
-Belgrade, Serbia
-Sarajevo, Bosnia
-Mostar, Bosnia
-Dubrovnik, Croatia
-Split, Croatia
-Zagreb, Croatia

My favorite places were Budva, Belgrade, Mostar and Split (especially Mostar and Split). Zagreb was very very cool too, but super fucking cold at the time, so didnt really get a chance to check it out properly like I would have liked to.

My least favorite place was Sarajevo, but still worth checking out just to cross it off the list I guess. I dont want to talk bad about the city because they went through absolute hell not too long ago, and the people are super nice and humble, but I found the city to be pretty lacking in "common sense" I guess, for lack of a better word, and its an extremely frustrating place where things don't work like they should and nothing seems to make sense. Also they try too hard to be "Western European" and the place is littered with lame French Bistros and Italian Restaurants and finding good local food besides fucking chivapi sausage in shitty tourist trap style cafes is fucking impossible. Not a bad city, but not very "comfortable" and I just couldn't synchronize with the place. Dubrovnik was pretty nice but overrated and expensive and boring, the place is practically tailor made for bored aging German wine aunts to snap Instagram selfies of themselves and nothing else.

Oh and if you go to Serbia, be prepared to be taken in the back area and questioned by your local Customs/Border Agents upon return to your home country. Really though, Belgrade is no different than anywhere else in Europe- hostels, cafes, restaurants, bars, clubs, museums, etc, so there is nothing to be afraid of. But just a head ups that its geopolitically frowned upon to go there right now and you might be specifically questioned/interviewed why you were there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not a first time JP tourist, N2, - let me tell you a story.
>December pretty bad, economic and everything wise.
>Nice apartment goes for rent, not to bad at about 900 USD/month. We're talking 45sqm or so, 2 mins from Shinjuku, yes really. Old build of 2008 but good enough. 1LDK, separate bath and toliet.
>Paid for everything remote, key money, move in, rent, etc.
>Didn't go Dec.
>Paid Jan, showed up a week ago.
>Decide not to really be in JP this year.
At this point it isn't that bad, we're talking a loss of $2400, which is nothing - but just a hassle.
I missed JP and nostalgia came over me - but the past few days have been meh. I was going in for the angle of getting a cheap apartment before the sprint tourists show up.

Met up/catched up with friends, many of them are 5yr+ in JP, some married/settled down with JP and they're all deciding to fly out, don't blame them really.

Thought about doing some small biz, self sponsered visa, etc - not a big deal - but the work for it just makes annoying. Already run 2 biz, one in USA and one in Asialand. JP seems comfy because it is a great layover spot and a cheap place would be great - but, it does seem a sharehouse would've worked much better at a quarter of the fees.

And that's it. The apartment is the best I've ever had being in JP outside of new build sharehouses but I just don't have time to fuck around as I did 5-8 years ago and that's sad.

I'm still catching up with everyone I know here, and that is nice, and JP is still great - literally 0 tourists, even at the meetup groups. Car rental is not even 1200JPY/day and I had a blast driving around. All the things you guys post on here are cute, but I would say they are worse than 5yrs ago. The girls are super thirsty though and easier, but, they're boring imo. They always were to me. I never liked JP girls, or much of anime. At best music and food.

I do have fun saying I can't speak much Japanese and then act like I'm a natural. It's fun.

AMA /reddit/

>>2389542
Wrote a whole post and then the browser refreshed and I lost it. Fark.
Basically, i'm on a 3 month Eurotrip and packed more than I needed despite going through freezing temps, snow, rain, heat, wind.
My tips for you are:
Realise you're going to be wearing the same clothes more often than you think. Same socks for 3 days, same shirt for 5 days, same pants for 2 weeks, etc.
Anti-perspirant is your friend as it'll stop you stinking up your clothes after you've only worn them for a day.
Every city is going to have a laundromat so the chances of you getting stuck with no clothes to wear is unlikely. If you're overly paranoid though or travelling somewhere you doubt there will be laundromats, pack a clothes washing soap bar.
Depending on where you're going all you really need is 1 scenario-specific outfit (by that I mean a "going out" outfit or a "hiking" outfit) and even then, try and fit that with your everyday outfit. For example, a "going out" outfit might just be your everyday jeans with a nice shirt rather than bringing nice jeans and a nice shirt. If you're going hiking your everyday shirt will be fine and more often than not, so will your everyday jeans.

Of course if you're a woman you're probably going full wacko mode and you're going to pack shit you don't need regardless. My gf has done this but even she recognises she's packed too much and has "nicer" clothes that she's hardly worn because at the end of the day when you're travelling and you're tired of catching buses and trains all day and it's freezing cold and you're hungry, you don't give a fuck about what you're wearing you just want to be comfortable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390406
Merino wool are top tier as base layers for hikes and mountaineering. Also comfy as shit as general winter baselayers like longjohns and long-sleeved undershirts in cold climates.
Wool is very warm as it creates many insulating air layers next to your skin. Critically, it's one of few materials that will keep trapping heat even when wet, hence the popularity as a base layer. It is terrible against wind though, a cotton tshirt will block more windchill than a $50 wool undershirt so you need another layer.

I suppose it's practical for the purposes you wrote as well but if you plan on wearing it instead of a t-shirt day to day you'll probably get pretty warm when indoors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390409
But if you plan to do hiking you should at least avoid cotton since, as you know, cotton shirts gets soaked and cold when wet. In colder climates this means that you'd have to change the shirt whenever you break to avoid getting cold (which is absolutely doable). You can avoid that discomfort with a woolen baselayer though. For warmer climates sticky wet cotton shirts are still uncomfortable so I'd prefer a in part synthetic work-out shirt.

I agree with others that in your current state it’s deeply unrealistic to think that relocating is going to solve your psychological and social problems. Regarding mental health, while a lot of depressive types get a lift from the excitement, distractions, and novelty of travel, at least temporarily, you’re going to bring whatever is wrong with you with you, and you’re going to need to have some kinds of tools and resources for getting better already under your belt—therapy? Medication? Something—before you leave or you will be disappointed. There are also a lot of new stressors involved when suddenly in a foreign environment, perhaps including language barriers and legal/visa/immigration bureaucracy, and it is almost certainly going to be harder to get mental health care in a foreign country than it is at home. I’m a legal immigrant with all my paperwork and medical insurance in good order, but because I’m only an intermediate speaker of the local language it took me months to find a therapist who could work in English.

Also, do you already know what you’re going to need to start a business where you’re going? Do you already have the right to live there, for that matter, or do you know how to get it? This stuff isn’t automatic and can be hard to navigate, all the harder if you’re not in a good place mentally.

Not saying you shouldn’t give it a shot, or that it won’t work, but this post makes it seem like you’re expecting a lot and maybe don’t know what you’re doing. So I encourage you to be better prepared than you sound before you make the leap.

>>2387961
My immigration is great, thanks. And it sounds like you’re at least starting to make a plan, which is good. My biggest piece of additional advice as you keep thinking things through is this, and I think it is extremely important:

You probably have (or will soon have) some estimate in your head of how much money you will be bringing with you when you arrive. However much money that is, double it, at least, before you get on the plane. Even in low-COL countries, initial outlays are going to be more than you think they will be, and you’re certain to run into expenses you weren’t anticipating at all. Housing, for example, even in poor countries, is almost always more expensive for foreigners who don’t have local connections. It will be especially expensive if you are arriving without legal, long-term residency (for example, just showing up in a country that lets your nationality in visa-free for 90 days, or six months, or even a year). Without some kind of residency document, you’re not likely to be able to sign a normal lease, so at least at first you will probably be stuck with short-term accommodations aimed at foreigners. These are going to be more expensive than whatever locals pay in rent, so even if you research average rents in your arrival city you won’t get an accurate picture of what it will really cost YOU.

Getting legally established is gong to cost more than you think it will, as well, almost without question. If you eventually change your visa status, you may be required to return to your home country to finalize the process at an embassy. You’ll get your new visa only when you come back, so you’ll want to budget for at least one trip home. MAYBE you will be able to get the paperwork done in-country, or maybe you’ll just have to hop a border to a neighboring country, but don’t count on it. Budget for the most expensive of these possibilities to avoid shock.

>Cont’d

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2388301
It’s also unwise to compare whatever money you expect to be earning (online, with your future business, etc.) with average local incomes, or worse yet, with GDP per capita, which is practically meaningless. Maybe the average local is only earning $XXXX per year. He’s also living with his extended family in a home owned by his grandparents and spending less on food than you will ever know how to, so even if you are bringing in $XXXX x 2 per year you aren’t going to be as rich as you think you are. And if you’re spending 90% of what you earn every month it can be kind of scary—living hand-to-mouth even someplace cheap is difficult.

You should also absolutely always have some kind of a cushion of emergency money. It is absolutely possible that things will be amazing, and it’s also possible that things will go to shit and you’ll have to fuck off back to mom and dad’s, maybe in a hurry. I sure hope not, but the sensible choice is to be able to afford such a possible outcome.

Women are very beautiful and for me that is important.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2376275
Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

>>2381428
Here's the Cyberpunk rankings of the cities I've visited so far:

Tokyo (7/10) (overated- too clean and tidy)
Seoul (7/10) (overated- has too much of a boring American "grid" like layout)
Busan (8/10) (underated- multiple skyscraper urban cores tucked in between mountains and hills filled with favela looking "slums", good mix of grit and modern/sleek)
Kyoto (0/10) (Asking if Kyoto is Cyberpunk is like asking if Florence, Italy is Cyberpunk. No.)
Jakarta (6/10) (too "low life" and not enough "high tech", its just a giant open sewer slum with some high end shopping malls in the center)

Some others
Bangkok (9/10) (100% Blade Runner/Night City, my favorite on this list, only reason its not a 10 is because I havent been to China yet which I imagine would take all perfect 10/10 rankings)
Saigon (8/10) (the "low life" aspect among neon grit is well represented, but a little lacking in the balance of modern infrastructure, skyscrapers and urban verticality outside of a very small area of District 1- give it time though, the city is building up fast and will probably take a 10/10 spot some day)

Keep in mind, this was all before COVID though- 2018 and 2019- and I imagine lockdowns killed any sort of that Cyberpunk "wild west", hustle and bustle feeling these places used to have. I imagine theyre all a lot quieter now and all the small businesses are mostly shuttered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389863
In short, if youre not a moron you'll be fine. Most if not all transportation methods have English signage and audio announcements. Traveling around will be no problem. Not all but a lot of restaurants have pictures of the plate so you can point and say "kore, kudasai", some will even have English menus that will be given to you if you don't look japanese.
You should get a translator for sure. Example the first time I went to Japan I saw a old wooden sign by a creek, took a pic, and translated it. It said "Don't fish the fish, keep the river clean, please." And you can do the same with menus in places that don't have pics or English.

posts.com: /biz/let here, leaning on /trv/ for some guidance. Please share some tips for Mardi Gras. Arriving in NOLA on the 18th of February, will be there for 5 days. Anons who have gone, share stories. How do my friends and I have a great time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389662
1. Go to Antoine’s. In the French Quarter Fine dining, French cuisine. Do NOT dress casual. Very cheap, complete meal with champagne should cost around 35-40$ if you get the premium items.
2. Johnny’s Po Boys is kind of mid but if you aren’t planning on going outside of New Orleans to taste traditional creole food it’s great.
3. If possible go to a outlying city such as Baton Rouge and get some Boudin (pronounced Boudan and locals get uppity if you pronounce it boudin and will correct you while seething)
3. Take ghost tour of cemetery. It’s stupid but fun.
4. Do NOT book at the Omni or the the W Hotel (Omni is shoebox+ expensive)people will scream and throw shit and you can hear it all night at the W) if cheap enough, go to the Westin. That’s the best place to go and only 5-8 minute walk to French quarter and 10-15 to bourbon street.
5. Go to Cafe Du Monde, but bring a drink beforehand. Drinks are ridiculously expensive there and the beignets will fry you like a motherfucker. Wait times will be anywhere from 15-50 minutes so plan accordingly.
6. Go to Fritzel’s. It’s a jazz club and very kino. Has the authentic New Orleans feel and vibe. Be early or you will not get a seat.
7. Do not take up any people who offer free drinks or anything on the street. They will hustle you. Don’t be a retard and you will be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You already bought it so what does it matter? I'd get one twice the size but fuck it. Just try it. If you find it's too small you can buy a complementary one like a duffel bag and strap it onto your backpack or just buy a new bigger one and switch. There are cheap knockoffs everywhere but generally the quality is shit which is unacceptable for backpacks. If you need to buy a new bag go to a mall in a big city like bkk or kl and pay regular global prices for global brands at an air-conditioned outdoors store. Be careful even in those stores though, they often carry unknown Chinese brands in add to the standard North face/ospray stuff. This Chinese stuff can be the real deal made for the serious Chinese Upper middle class but can just as well be the same fake bullshit you'll find in the streets and there's no way for a farang to tell.
Or you could complement your backpack with literal plastic bag in the worst case. You just carry it from the hostel to the tuk-tuk and then onto the bus/plane, to the next tuk-tuk or taxi and into your next room.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I mean the biggest factors to take into consideration are

>length of hike/excursion
>willingness to clean/replenish contents at regular intervals
>how packed the bag will be

The last point is especially important to consider because there's no way you're getting a giant pack on the plane unless you want to roll the dice on overhead compartment space. As far as actually getting around goes, you'll want to make sure the bag is packed right to combat shoulder and back fatigue. I didn't see any lower back support offered in the other pics, which is going to stink. The pack looks like it's built well but designed for maybe three or four days worth of stuff without overpacking it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>is Puerto Rico worth visiting?
Yes 100%. Most tourists go to San Juan/Carolina, and maybe take a trip to El Yunque and Farajado. Old San Juan is very fun, walk around and look at beautiful homes and gardens and amazing views of the ocean in nearly every direction. Locals still live and work there which makes it feel more authentic. Easy to air b&b. Condado is very popular place to stay as well, like a small Miami but on the ocean and filled with hot wealthy tourists that want to party and have sex. Book El yunque trips with a group or request a government pass very far in advance, rent a car and try and go off the path if you can but pass is needed for that. Farajado has bioluminescence bay very popular for tourist to kayak there

>clear water or dirty water?
Very clear water but depending on where you are it will either be an average local beach or a beautiful tourist beach. You have to find a beach they aren’t surrounding the whole island. Check out culebra and vieques islands if you want to see world famous gorgeous beaches, easy to get there from farajado

>how are the locals? Extremely nice and friendly in the nice areas. More so than most Americans. There is a huge class divide. If you go to poor area it can become extremely dangerous. Speak basic Spanish to communicate English is not spoken. Act like you would in any unfamiliar city

>places to avoid?
Much of San Juan surrounding the ocean side of the bay and old city is very safe even at night but beyond that should be avoided. the tourist part of the city is overall a very small section of San Juan. Don’t go past Miramar is a good limit for the average tourist who does not know what streets are good and bad

Also your image is a very very old ghetto from the beginning of the island history placed outside the walls between the two main forts. San Cristobal and El Morro. A shantytown called La Perla. Stay out of there, you have to work hard to find a way in so don’t worry

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389258
PRfag here. It's a good place to vacation but horrible to live in. So glad I gtfo but I still go in winter to see family and escape the cold. I'm actually taking some friends back this spring.
>places to see?
Old San Juan, Condado, La Placita en Santurce and Miramar (mostly Av. de la Constitucion and Calle Cerra) are the main hub downtown. Isla Verde is good for beach bumming near downtown and has an OK array of bars and restaurants. The real hub of life is downtown in old san juan though.

Outside of downtown, there's the Yunque rainforest (must book online before going now for parking and coof protection bs) and the dry forest of guanica for hiking. We have 3 bioluminescent bays, the better one being in Vieques. The one in La Parguera sometimes has sharks who use the bay as a nursery but it's overall safe. Fajardo's kayak tour sucks, find a local with a small boat who will let you swim in the water instead (more easily done in vieques' mosquito bay and la parguera).
>beaches?
Ocean Park and Isla Verde near downtown. Mar Chiquita near Manati, Rincon beaches for surfing, take a catamaran to Icacos and Palomino from Fajardo or to Caja de Muertos from Salinas or Ponce. If you dont mind a rougher ocean but kino rich mode beach bum vacation go to Palmas del Mar. Flamenco Beach in Culebra is also kino but the ferry service to get there is a nightmare to deal with. The water is good, but its best in Icacos/Palomino/Caja de Muertos and Flamenco Beach. Culebra > Vieques for beaches btw.
>locals?
Pretty friendly typically, but they are either poor and ghetto (cafre/caco) or wealthy and somewhat cultured. The closer you are to the downtown niceties the nicer the people because they're generally wealthier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390327 (cont.)
>Avoid
La Perla in Old San Juan is to be avoided entirely, it's the only hot spot in the entire area. Condado's rule of thumb is the closer to the shoreline (ashford ave.) the safer it gets. For Miramar, stick to av de constitucion and calle cerra, the rest gets real sketch real fast. When it comes to La Placita, youve got an actual plaza and a few streets near it that are safe. I wouldn't go further south past La Penultima (solid bar btw) or too far directly east/west of it by foot. North of it is Condado which will get progressively safer the further north you go. Santurce is overall not the safest place but not hellish either. Lote 23 is a decent hangout for food trucks, same with the Miramar food trucks one (those handmade dumplings are great and they have a bar truck) too.

I had a full copypasta prepped a long time ago for PR threads so I'll dump it for you:
>La Placita (go on a Friday night)
Notable bars to check here are Jungle Bird and La Penultima. Tasca el pescador for seafood, Santaella for local and great (but pricey) food/drinks.
>Old San Juan (Saturday)
La Factoria is a great bar (23+ to enter) with additional "speakeasy" bars if you walk past the saloon doors. Casa de Montecristo is a top tier cigar lounge with one of the best stocked bars in the island and a beautiful interior, go even if you dont smoke. La Cubanita is good. La Grieta is a great mezcal bar. La verguenza is more dive bar but has 3 floors and nice views. La taberna lupulo is a beer hall with an open air indoor patio you can smoke and drink at. Big local beers are trash, avoid Medalla and Magna, stick to Ocean Labs or FOK brews for better local beer. Dining in VSJ is varied and depends on what you're in the mood for, yelp it up to decide since there's too many recs for this. Do not go to La Perla or you risk being robbed, it's the high crime area of vsj and a literal historic ghetto though its mostly safe to visit during big events like Las Calles de San Sebastian.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390332 (cont.)
>El Yunque Rainforest
Book in advance now because covid, go in a swimsuit for the waterfall dips, bring water and some snacks + backpack. On the way out, get lunch or dinner at La Parrilla at los kioskos de luquillo (luquillo kiosks). It's the only one worth going to there and don't recommend staying much longer after. Luquillo has nice beaches, but is a lot more impoverished and can get sketchy.
>Rio Grande
Beach resorts galore. St. Regis is top tier and they have beach apts and golf carts you can rent but its pricey. Wyndham Rio Mar is a more affordable hotel, but you may be better off renting a beach house/apt there to save cash.
>Palmas del mar
Alternative to RG for beach bumming with a beach house. Rougher beaches but much more upscale, extremely safe area but pricey. Make sure your rental includes a golf cart to get around in, buy booze outside the area. The Don Rey cigar shop in Palma Nova has a solid selection too.
>Dorado
Rich people vacation homes similar to Palmas and hosts the only 6 star hotel on the island if you want to go all out with money spending. The beaches here are not my favorite because they are too soft for my taste since I like rougher waves.
>Rincon
More beach bumming with emphasis on surfing, it is THE spot to surf at. Literally nothing else to do here besides drink and swim.
>La Parguera
Beach bumming with the house on top of the water. Get a kayak or a boat tour to the bioluminescent bay and if you roll boat tour, make sure they let you take a dip in the water. best on nights with little moonlight. 45 min drive from Ponce if you want to see the "southern capitol" of PR.
>Culebra or Vieques
Fajardo ferry can take you there, must go very early morning and prices will rise as those islands have no sustainability without the main PR island. Culebra has better beaches, Vieques has a bioluminescent bay. Whichever you prefer is up to you, I'd say go Culebra.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390338
>Food
1. La cuevita del mar/Cayo Caribe, one of the original owners of cuevita split and made cayo, both are excellent seafood restaurants. Seafood mofongo best start. Mofongo is a plaintain bowl filled with meat/fish/chicken and topped with sauce, staple in cuisine. As a side dish, its served plain and is not as good as stuffed.
2. La Parrilla @ Luquillo is your best bet for humongous lobster or my personal favorite, whole fried snapper. This should be your go to stop after a day of hiking at the rainforest or a must visit if you stay at Rio Grande.
3. El Cuñao is a restaurant in the mountains near Cayey, go here for tons of local dishes but most notably Lechon (whole pork skewered on a rod and roasted over a fire, then served piece by piece). Morcillas (Blood sausage stuffed with rice and spices), longaniza (Spanish style sausage), Arroz con gandules (Rice and beans), Amarillos (fried sweet instead of salty plantain) are all good here, and the drive is quite nice.
4. Sandwich Shops: Kasalta in Condado and La Ceiba near Plaza las Americas mall are good. After a night of drinking in VSJ, at the bottom streets west of the cruise docks go grab a Tripleta from a food truck (pork, ham and chicken/steak/sausage sandwich) or get one at an El Churry food truck. Pinnky's in Condado is also delicious.
5. Bottles - Near San Patricio Plaza, top tier dining, expensive af but its family style so you get portions for a family of 4 when you order. Lots of wine as well, no reservations so go early
6. La Lanterna - NY 5 star tier dining in VSJ. Italian restaurant. Will tie with bottles for most expensive but portions will not be as big, you get what you pay for though.
7. Calle Loiza (Condado) is ghettoish, but has great restaurants all over. In Condado, La bodeguita de manolo is great as is Cocina Abierta for expensive fine dining.
8. La Picara by Chef Xiomy. Fine dining, really good.
9. Compostela, Spanish and Seafood. Can't go wrong with anything ordered here.

How much would it cost for a 6 months backpacking trip to Thailand and SEA in general?

I'm planning on quitting my shitty 9-5 job this April but I wanna know how much money I need.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This was quite a few years ago in Thailand, Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam for 6 months:
I used on avarage 1100 USD/month not counting the Europe - bkk flights or vaccines and gear bought before the trip.
I was staying in dorms, bungalows or cheap hotels and living off of cheap street food and beer. Included in the $1100 / month were all expenses such as transportation (buses, boats, train, flights) and the following activities:
>Thai boxing two week course
>recreational diving license (padi basic+advanced) and a few additional dives throughout the trip
>1 week climbing course
>motorbike rentals for a total period of at least 5 weeks.
>some touristic mekong delta three day all inclusive tour with a shit load of brits and Americans.
>various touristy day activities and tours like bike rentals, boat tours, etc.
Also included would be a new phone I bought for around $250 since my old one broke and I bought various souvenirs and gear all over the place.

I don't know about prices today but if you don't want to do any of those activities you can probably get by with less while somewhere around 1200-1500 / month should give you a similar standard.

>>2389793
>How much would it cost for a 6 months backpacking trip to Thailand and SEA in general
Depends entirely on what you want to do there, how long you'll stay in one place, etc. Bare minimum probably:
>Short term accomodation: probably around $300-400 a month depending on whether or not you're using airbnbs, hostels, etc. The biggest variable
>Food: ~$150-300 a month depending on appetite, willingness to cook own food occasionally, nutritional or dietary restrictions, etc
>Other misc expenses: ~$200/mo
>then add up the cost of anything you may want to do activity wise
I'd say no less than $1000/mo NOT including initial and final flights. If you're willing to stay 3 months in a city you can easily cut accommodation costs by half.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: When you visit a country how do you develop an itinerary? Do you do things impulsively or fully research where you will be going? If so what websites/blogs/channels do you take inspiration, thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Decide on what country/city to go to
>Google Top 10 places to see in said country/visit
>Add what I want to see to Google maps
>Read a bit of said places to find out details like how to get there, price, etc
>Decide on what day to visit place that piques my interest most, often consider it the "main" event
>Look on Google maps to see which other areas of interests are close by and do those as secondary
>Check TripAdvisor/GetYourGuide to see what activities might be worth doing
>Have an extra day to either backtrack, check on things you miss or be impulsive

You can be as loose or as rigid as you like. Dont have to stick to the plan either, but it helps to have a plan at least and knowing where to go.

Anyway, I think you’re underestimating how difficult life as an undocumented immigrant really is, even in countries where you don’t stick out as glaringly as you do in Japan. Without proper papers you’re cut off from basic everyday life activities that require legal contracts: real jobs, bank accounts, credit, housing in your own name, healthcare. You’re limited to the black market and the margins, which makes you vulnerable to exploitation and shuts you out of all but the lowest rungs of society. It’s a precarious way to live at best. That isn’t to say you can’t survive this way for some time, perhaps even years, but you’re not going to establish yourself or contribute in any kind of long-term or productive way.

>>2387833
Never mind. My point was, most universities from any given country, your home country included, have exchanges and double diploma deals with chinese universities. Your best bet would be to integrate those for a Master's degree. You then basically have the length of your studies there to do some networking, find a job or a PhD. It will not be easy but it is possible if you stay there and look long enough. Also, you need to seriously work on your Chinese. Since you're not doing STEM in an international corpo or TEFL, you're basically competing directly with the chinese in a domain where they don't recruit much foreigners. You could contend, but you have to even up the playing field, and that goes by learning mandarin.

Don't try to directly apply for a Chinese university if you're doing a pol sci cursus. You might end up with mandatory classes taught in mandarin, which would then put you in big trouble, because pol sci taught in chinese means you're going to write a shit ton of essays in chinese, which requires an advanced mastery of the language.

But in any case, learning Chinese is a must. If you're serious about this, i suggest you get started right away. You could taking classes IRL or online to get started. Classes can be as cheap as 9 bucks an hour on Preply, for example.

Oh one last point, like I said, China may not be an ideal immigration destination. It's pretty conservative, permanent residency is pretty much impossible to get so you'll always be hanging on your work visa and your employers which can be a shitty predicament long term.

>>2388585
Sociology isn't something that is in great demand to start with no matter the country, except in education and HR and HR, well, you're competing with literally billions of locals since HR is low skill work and is about interpersonal relations (meaning, a perfect mastery of Chinese).
He's boasted in a video (or rather his wife) that he has a HSK5 which is the equivalent of having a C1. According to chinese teaching associations in germany and france, as well as the TOCFL commitee, an HSK5 from before 2021 is basically B1 or very low B2. Why am I pointing this out ? Because sociology is an essay and analysis heavy course, and a professor or a lecturer would have to teach that in Chinese. Which he couldn't possibly manage. He could've taught the courses in english, but even then english courses have such a low volume in any university it wouldn't justify the expenditure of hiring a lecturer let alone a professor. So it only makes sense that he was hired by the language faculty of the university and not the social studies one.

This being said, in all honesty OP, political science is basically the same. Polsci is about becoming a state worker (which you can't really be besides professor because you'll never be chinese), or other shit that will require you to have a perfect drive of the chinese language. A PhD and I'm speaking from experience (and the spanish guy who did one said it also), can't be done while you're learning high level Chinese. You won't have the time. And getting anywhere near an HSK5 would take you around 3 years of weekly courses. In other words, switch fields. Can't have the cake and eat it too.

>>2389391
Anything is possible. OP hasn't specified whether he wanted to work in the field in which he graduated.
To be honest, the main trick is to actually be there, meet people, and then tailor your search to what is possible and you need. Working your chinese definitely improves your odds, but what better time to do so while you're there ? Sure, you can work in advance and get a headstart but ultimately, there is a real chance that you'll find some work. I haven't thus far met someone who's been on a 1 year quest of looking for a job with boots on the ground who hasn't found some type of employment with a visa, and i'm not talking native english speakers or devs here.
Do an exchange (make sure it's your last semester) or get a double diploma (the keyword you're looking for in spanish is "doble master"). That way you still get the masters from your home country (and in the case of the double diploma, both diplomas, which is ideal) but most importantly, you have a visa that allows you to stay there and figure out the job market. Most student retards will go to party and have the fun of their lives and stick together ignoring the chinks and banging the hoes, but you'll be around the long term foreigners to try to get a job for your last 6 months of stay. Other alternative would be to go for broke and instead of applying for a masters, apply for a chinese language student visa with a scholarship, and use the time you'll spend there to study chinese and look for a job.
All these options, while expensive, will have their cost heavily offset by the fact that China has an overall low cost of life, so you'll probably end up spending as much money getting a masters in spain as you would in China if that can be of any solace.

Also, *again*, it would REALLY help if you spoke Chinese.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My taste became a lot more bourgeois when I got married—my wife has higher standards for comfort than I do, and we have enough money now that semi-expensive hotels aren’t a problem for us. I wouldn’t enjoy spending $1000+/night, but I can’t remember the last time we spent less than $200 except in developing countries, and in expensive cities we have very often spent a lot more than that.

I have vivid memories of the moment my perspective shifted, back when I was still a young poor cheapskate backpacker. My now-wife insisted we move out of the <$10/night concrete cell with the bare lightbulb hanging from the ceiling that I had found for us in Thailand, and into the (maybe as much as $40/night?) hotel across the street. Fine, I admit it, yeah, this bed isn’t hard as a rock, and the lighting isn’t dismal, and it looks cleaner, and the hot shower and air-con do actually make me noticeably more comfortable. Better hotel wins.

A similar logic applies to how we use hotels now. Spending more than the cheapest price available guarantees at least somewhat, sometimes far, better comfort and details. But eventually there’s a diminishing return in my opinion—most midrange/4-star/business hotels are totally boring, especially chains, and the luxuries you get in 5-star++ places and resorts can be fun for novelty or a special treat, but seem stupid to insist on. Most luxury amenities, maybe apart from fancy-pants showers and baths and high-end bathrobes that are guaranteed to actually be clean, are wasted on me personally.

If you’re young and poor it can be a blast to splurge on a higher-end hotel and pretend to be rich for a few days. But as someone who is now old and sort of rich, I find that I get my favorite results from interesting smaller guesthouses or boutique hotels that are neither the most economical nor the most expensive.

You get 60 days when you arrive at the airport. Then you go to an immigration office and they extend it another 30 days. After 30 days you take a day trip to Vietnam. As for why it isn't longer? You know the US should demand that it get better entry options than the EU passport holders but Americans don't travel overseas enough to know better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2388890
The last great dodgy visa scam appears to be the year-long visas that some language schools are still offering. You will be required to actually attend a few hours of language class every week (the school signs off on your visa, so it’s not likely you can fake or skip this), and check in with immigration every month, but ever since the pandemic started it’s been possible to do this without leaving the country (you used to get shorter visas that had to be renewed abroad when going through a private language school).

The immigration authorities have been complaining about these programs for several years now, and friends in the know in Bangkok are confident that its days are numbered. But it’s still possible at least for now.

Otherwise, your long-term stay options are an investor visa (good for a year at a time, renewable indefinitely as long as the value of your investment portfolio never dips below ten million baht at renewal time), marrying a local, enrolling in a real school (university), or starting a business that employs Thai people.

There’s a new ten-year visa program that’s just been rolled out, as well, but it’s extremely expensive. And there used to be a VIP 5-year visa for something like $20K that included goofy perks like concierge services and airport priority lanes, but I’m not sure if they’ve axed it yet.

>Do you have to apply separately at the airport for a 60day visa? I'm not seeing it on their website.
They were doing 60 day “special visas” (on arrival, maybe?) back when you still had to quarantine. Completely different from the 45-day visa exemptions, which you get automatically when showing up by air and don’t have to pay for.

You can still buy a 60-day tourist visa, but you have to do it in advance at an embassy or consulate (or have a travel agent do it for you if you are lazy or unable to locate an embassy or consulate). Can’t be done on arrival. Can also be extended once by 30 days before you have to leave the country to repeat the process, like the visa exemption.

Officially, however, neither of these things can be done indefinitely. In both cases, you’re only officially entitled to do it twice in a row in a given year, giving you a total of either 150 or 180 days in country in a given year. Subsequent returns are still possible at the discretion of immigration and border control officials, but the standard now appears to be that they’ll let you in a third time with a warning that they’re not doing it again. It’s also possible just to be refused entry on your third try.

I guess some people are still getting lucky and pulling it off for a longer period, but it’s not like the 90s when people stayed for years and years just on exemptions.

The big chains in the UK are almost all shit. Go to a chain pub, especially Wetherspoons and the food will be cheap, but shit. You need to put in effort to find good places to eat. The best meal you may have could be a no name pub on some country lane in the middle of nowhere or a random run down 'greasy spoon' cafe in a town centre.

Top British food:

Indian curries (by now, it's so different from actual Indian food, it's basically its own thing)
Roast beef and Yorkshire puddings (carveries in general)
Full English Breakfasts
General farm produce: Cheeses, sausages, back bacon, cider, ale
Afternoon tea (light lunch with tea where you have small sandwiches with scones and cakes) and cakes/desserts in general.
Fish and Chips
Steak and Ale pies, Cottage Pies, Lancashire hotpots, Steak and Kidney puddings

Another thing is that there's the whole concept of "filthy" food in the UK. Food that's cooked unhealthily in a way that maximises taste, presented messily and being the opposite of fine dining. Often food that's incredible after a night out or when hungover. Also possibly why there is such great street food and things like box parks

I’m not terribly surprised that flights to Laos are overpriced—Vientiane is a tiny airport with few connections. But it would be my first choice among the places you mention, although the visa regime there is at least as strict as that of VN, and you probably can’t stay very long.

But anyway, you probably already know that Bali is cheaper than Seoul, although I find Seoul quite affordable too—it’s noticeably less expensive than the US and European cities I’ve lived in. And either costs more than you’re spending in Hanoi. But they’re different enough to feel almost like separate planets: Seoul is a mostly-developed Northern megacity, Bali is a still-developing tropical island with a few small cities, many rural districts, and a lot of resorts. And too many shitfaced Australians.

Some friends who’ve been doing a round the world trip for the last year and a half liked Bali a lot for some very stylish coworking spaces they found there, some of which were also guesthouses. Easier place to find other digital nomads, assuming you’re doing something like that and can stand the company of other DNs.

I would probably choose whichever place has the most convenient visa options for you if you intend to stay long-term and neither choice seems obvious.
